text: That last bit about the warming from CO2 wasn't presented as dubious, and that I fear is politics, not science. The amount of warming CO2 produces (apparently some) is not precisely known. The role of the sun and how it warms the planet is not well understood either (probably something to do with cosmic rays, and their effect on clouds). This isn't something I know, of course, but I take my science opinions from people I deem experts (there is no other option), and Freeman Dyson (RIP) looks like a reliable expert... not worried about his job, not worried about money personally or funding for his department, not likely susceptible to peer pressure, and also someone capable of understanding all the science of CO2 and claims of experts in the quasi-science of climate prediction. Those are his opinions. I wonder why the tens of thousands of admittedly lesser scientists form opinions contrary to such an expert who was, when he died, the foremost physicist in the world and someone known for his imagination and the breadth and depth of his knowledge of the physical world.

text:
You forgot to mention a crucial step in why Antarctica got so extremely colder than any land or sea range has ever been since the Cambrian Explosion: 
The collapses of both the Isthmus of Magellan and the Isthmus of Tasmania, the last slivers of land to define the existence of Gondwana.

The second of these collapses was key, and thanks to some weird fossils found in a mountain valley in the Antarctic highlands that has been protected from glacier formation and movement, we now know to within 10,000 years when it occurred:
19,400,000 years ago. 
About a million years before that, going back to 40 million years ago, the land connection between Antarctic and Australia had thinned down to Isthmus status, being both stretched, north to south, by tectonic force and worn away, east to west, by ocean current and waves.
It would have been a treacherous bit of land to cross, however, as warm tropical waters from the Barring Reef were channeled down the east side, bringing warm air with it, while cold winds brought by even colder water on the west side, would cross over to mix with the warm, creating endless water spouts or sea tornadoes that would have regularly crossed the land bridge. Consequently, once this cycle reached a certain zenith, the bridge became impassable to all but the toughest and luckiest critters millions of years before the collapse.
But the important thing is that the bit of continental shelf that remained continued to channel warm water and air to the Southern Continent, which in turn kept the 41,000 year climate swings of the planet even between North and South poles, same as they had always been, excepting for very gradual slowing of the earth’s rotation. 
That changed VERY suddenly 19,400,000 years ago. 
The part of the Isthmus that could have even theoretically been crossed on foot had been so worn down as to sink beneath the waves, but an INCREASINGLY sheer wall of rock still arose up miles above the abyssal plain, 100 feet or less beneath the waves, still channeling the warm jet stream that 95%of life in Antarctica still depended on. 
Then, perhaps an Big earthquake caused several miles of the wall to collapse all at once along its thinnest part, and this caused the jet stream to immediately be redirected around the new Tasmanian peninsula into South Western Australia waters, which had been cool and temperate up to then, which no doubt had a sudden negative impact there as well.
But that’s small potatoes compared to the devastation the sudden loss of the last trickle of warm water had in Antarctica.
Less then a year later, 80% of all plant and animal life had frozen solid. Perhaps some REALLY hardy scavengers lingered on the frozen carcasses of all other creatures for a few more years. But if this had happened in just the last 100,000 years, we would have found vast frozen dead forests, perfectly preserved as they were in the last weeks of their lives. 
Perfectly preserved as the plants and pond animals in that highland valley still are. 
However, glaciers have since erased all other evidence of that world.
If Antarctica were to thaw, it would become like Michigan on steroids, the Land of a Million Lakes, with enough sand to build a full scale sandcastle for everyone on earth.

text:
ninthRing 
Here’s an important question: 
How many whole taxonomic GENERA and FAMILIES are endangered? As far as I can tell, what we are actually losing in large numbers are subspecies and highly specialized species with plenty of less specialized cousins within the same Genus doing just fine elsewhere. 
I’m not saying we should just let that happen, but neither is it the gloom and doom you think it to be.
Let’s not fall into nihilistic self destruction over a poor understanding of the details.
Furthermore, if it really IS as bad as you fear, why are your fellow activists (not necessarily you personally) so irrationally focused on putting all the blame on the Western countries?
If you are TRULY committed towards doing whatever it takes to save the earth from this threat, then you should be advocating for the western conquest of China. 
Stop fooling yourselves, they beat EVERYONE in how they pollute in utterly hypocritical abandon by a 100 miles, the next worse polluters in Africa don’t even come close, and NO ONE is coming in third close to them. 
Anyone taking climate change as deadly serious SHOULD demand we use all available means to FORCE China to stop, including outright conquest. The resulting war could not possibly be worse than what’s already coming, right? What have we got to lose, and everything to gain, by bringing their terracidal behavior to heel?
90% of all plastic in the ocean comes from 8 Chinese rivers and 2 African rivers. America contributes maybe 2%. 
They wiped out their native honey bees throughout their southeast through sheer bureaucratic stupidity, and farmers have to pollinate their crops BY HAND.
But what SHOULD be making your blood run cold with rage and terror is that China has between 2,000-5,000 new deep seam coal fires burning out of control since 1950, because they simply have no genuine consistent safety Standards. America has had only 5 new ones in that time, and 4 were from old abandoned, poorly sealed mines that some idiots caused by playing with fire near the entrances.
Only ONE of ours has been caused by workplace incompetence. 
Now, there’s a rare naturally occurring deep seam coal fire in Australia that was probably caused by erosion and a lightning strike. It’s been estimated to have been burning for 6,000 years. 
There is no known way to stop these fires, and they just keep pumping carbon into the air LONG after locals stop using coal. 
What are you prepared to do to stop this from getting worse?

text:
@Glen Be  There's a tremendous amount of evidence gathering that point more towards an impact event triggering the Younger Dryas and setting the extinction of all the mega-fauna in motion. So . . . climate change that started with the melting of the northern ice sheets producing mega-floods accompanied by massive flora fires and sea level rise of 130 meters {wiping out the coastal graze} and 1,300 years of winter. By the time the warming trend could pick back up, mega-fauna populations would have been crashed below the level of viability. The last of the mammoths died out around four thousand years ago. While humans 'could' and do wipe specie from existence, it would have been impossible for us to have wiped every specie over 40 kilos from the western hemisphere and northern Europe at the same time.


I might point out that the Milanković cycle is still theory, and one that has many issues with observations. Two of the cycles seem to have 'switched places' in importance this last spin. This theory also implies that the sun is a constant source, and that's nowhere near true. It's own cycles are probably far more relevant to our climate than our orbital postition.

text:
Talks about how human activities might impact the cycles as if we're going to be around in another 74,000 years when the next peak would be expected***
HA! That's rich. We've had factories and railway travel for less than 200 years and we're already putting ourselves at extreme risk by destroying the environment we depend on for existence and overpopulating the planet, combined with too much globalism, which results in VERY easy disease spreading as we're now realizing in 2020. 

Oh, I don't think we'll even make it another 1,000 years, much less 10,000 or ..74,000. That is a LONG time for the planet to put up with our stupidity without snuffing us out...and believe me, ask the dinosaurs, the universe has ways of making the guys on top go away pretty quickly. Only in our human arrogance would be presume ourselves poised to last another 74,000 years at the rate we're going. Our kind has scarcely been around 200,000 years (compare that with the 160 million + years the dinosaurs had) and we've only had organized societies for the last 8,000 years or so, and look where we are. We may wipe ourselves out with germ warefare, or nukes, or by essentially starving ourselves out of existence by destroying the environment, or baking ourselves out of existence by pumping all those gasses into the atmosphere and acting like it'll all be fine. 

Well, it WILL be fine. For the planet. The planet - and life on earth - will out-survive us by a wide margin. EVERY species goes extinct. Every single one. We are NO exception. We dream lofty dreams of sailing the stairs on faster-than-light ships, but the reality is...we have no feasible way of making that happen. Currently, our fastest-ever devices would still take us the better part of 20,000 years just to reach the nearest star, MUCH LESS the nearest HABITABLE planet, which is likely much, much, MUCH further than that. So no. We aren't going anywhere. Warp drives are not going to be a thing. Physics impose real limits on travel. Mars has next to no atmosphere and while we may land a few crafts or start a few colonies there, that's not going to save the species - if anything, a domed colony is INCREDIBLY fragile by nature. Decompression, disease, terrorism, micro-meteorites, radiation, any number of things can scrub a colony clean of human life. We're fragile beings - and we're learning that in 2020 as this virus spreads like wildfire and we just HOPE it won't mutate into something even deadlier. 

I'm only sad I won't be around in 74,000 years to see how long forgotten the human race is. I'll bet if I could travel to that time, I'd see the creeping glaciers, I'd see the beginnings of some new species - the first telltale mutations in some lifeforms that will lead to whole other species in the future - I'd feel the cold and...there would be no sign of US. Anywhere. Unless, perhaps, if I were to dig into the ground and come across the crumbled remains of our once-towering cities - now dust, rubble, and micro-plastics in a thin layer a few meters down. The animals above never being the wiser that once, there was a strange kind of primate that dominated these lands, so cocksure in its invincibility that it did nothing to prepare for the knockout punch that came its way - perhaps that punch was a sudden rise of extreme volcanism worldwide, or disease, a massive asteroid strike, MULTIPLE asteroid strikes, extreme climate shifts, or a combination of the above. A lot can change in just 74,000 years, as the dinosaurs found out one day about 65.5 million years ago.

Atmospheric CO2 is always at its lowest during glaciation and highest when earth is warmest - e.g., 130-115k years ago.
We need MORE CO2 to create more plants for more animals to eat and also absorb more CO2 - i.e., the virtuous Cycle of life.

text: Of course you don't need human influence for the climate to change, and sure there are a lot of factors humans can't do anything about, like Milankovich cycles, plate tectonics and volcanism. Hypothetically, if human civilization didn't contribute any accumulated CO2 and methane in the atmosphere, we would still have to adapt to the next glacial maximum once the current interglacial period was over. Much of northern Eurasia and northern North America would be practically uninhabitable. Now given the fact that we've raised the level of CO2 in the atmosphere to over 400 ppm some researchers suggest we could actually be postponing the next ice age by 100 000 years (https://www.nature.com/articles/nature16494), if our emissions over time amount to 1-1500 gigatons of cumulative CO2 (we pumped out 37 gigatons last year).  Even if most would argue that global warming will have much more imminent detrimental effects than the next ice age would with time, it is ultimately a kind of catch 22 situation for people living in the northern parts of the northern hemisphere.

text:
Incomplete. The process by which the cycles release or capture carbon must be told. The cycles are triggers of the cooling and heating processes -- NOT the process itself.  
When warming, it is CO2 being released from thawing permafrost that is the main cause of the warming. 
Currently, mankind is adding CO2 directly, triggering a warming cycle independent of the Malenkovich cycles. Our induced warming cycle is swamping the natural process, which would now be near to starting an ice age. Instead, we are creating a very warm period, possibly eventually becoming as warm as the Cretaceous.

text:
i believed the milankovitch cycles a while back were the cause of the ice age a while back, but i can't anymore due to symmetry problems. anything the earth does in space will have symmetry to it. so, if it takes 100k years to reach a low point, then it should take the same amount of time to reach a high point, like with the weather from the peak of summer to the trough of winter. you should never see 70k years of decline followed by a sudden 3k year upswing. the ice data this video shows at 9:15 is basically a heartbeat monitor. 


precession couldn't cause it either as the north pole is only pointing away from the sun at its most distant (eccentric) point for a little over 6,000 years, out of the whole 26,000 year cycle. this means the north pole points towards the sun for another 6000 years at it's most distant point, countering the glaciation. if the north pole leans toward the sun in the summer today, it has done so 4 times in the last 120k years.


obliquity, like precession will have the sun beating down heavier on the polar regions during the summer, meaning an equal swing in the opposite direction, not just one. also, the axial tilt is each year which means that ice would need to reform each year as the warmer summers would melt the ice.


but hey this is my opinion, not a subject based on any peer reviewed journal.

text:
Amazing. So a half dozen powerful natural and cyclical forces produce extreme climate changes. Yet the one small force that humans produce can stop climate change in its tracks. At least that's what we are being sold in the Green New Deal. 
How small is the one force under human control? First off it isn't the greenhouse effect. Humans only produce one fifth of the total greenhouse gas carbon dioxide--the rest is natural--and carbon dioxide is less than one fifth of total greenhouse effect--the rest is due to water vapor. 
So only one fifth of one fifth of the total greenhouse effect has anything to do with human activity--so humans contribute less than one twenty-fifth of the greenhouse effect--and the greenhouse effect itself is only one of the many, more powerful, natural forces described in this video. 
Meaning the climate is going to go right on changing regardless of what puny humans do about fossil fuels. 
And if we do nothing about fossil fuels, in another fifty to a hundred years technology will make renewables and nuclear energy cheaper and more abundant anyway, which will phase out fossil fuel by simple market forces. 
Case closed. The Green New Deal is a scam to create a global super-government. The elites win power, and the rest of us suck hind tit.

text:
It depends on how you measure it.  The 1C is generally considered to be the change that is above and beyond anything explicable by natural phenomena (cycles, volcanoes, spontaneous combustion, whatever.)
Unfortunately, scientists love to include all of the qualifiers and small print with every statement they make which is part of why people think they aren't trustworthy -- human nature leads us to believe in people with unwavering confidence, no matter how deserved (or not) it is and we tend to instinctively distrust any claims that come with caveats.  Anti-science nutjobs exploit that fact by exaggerating the qualifiers of things they don't agree with and minimizing the qualifiers of things they do, allowing them to confidently state "facts" that are technically true if you ignore all context, but don't actually line up with reality in any meaningful way.  See: anti-vaxxers.

author: Jon Mallary

text:
What stuck with me, and correct me if I'm wrong: 

a) Yes, climate cycles back and forth to ice ages and it does so  in cycles of 100.000 years.
b) We now seem to be roughly 25.000 year into the cycle down, towards an ice age.
c) When scientists measure global average temperatures going up it is not because of a natural climate cycle, it is despite of the natural climate cycle.

It seems the current western industrialization/civilization is going to show up as a short blip of a few hundred years within such a 100.000 year climate cycle.

I really wonder what fun we are heading for when fossil fuel for farm equipment runs out, overpopulation overshoots current food production and climate change makes more and more harvests go bad.

text:
Ah the Milankovitch cycles it is fascinating how their effects have played into the role of the role of climate variability but it should probably be worth noting that these effects are minor compared to other driving factors such as carbon dioxide and thus usually only emerge when the climate is near a carbon instability threshold where the planet is in between a Ice Free or hothouse state and the full snowball state that planet thankfully hasn't experienced since the Neoprotozoic. When working on my term paper for my atmospheric physics class it was fascinating to read about the Snowball Earth and the various interplays that precipitated the extreme climate shift and the Ice Albedo effect was one of the main drivers (though not the sole factor) but the Milankovitch cycles came into play there as the planet's CO2 levels and surface albedo changed (largely driven because ice precipitated mainly near the poles and sublimated near the Equator allowing the ice there to gradually darken thanks to particulates being left behind). Basically the cycles appear in between the full ice and full hothouse states when the climate gets near but not quite at a tipping point thankfully the Earth hasn't seen a full Snowball state since the Neoprotozoic where it seems it may have driven our ancestors to become multi-cellular to survive Perhaps we could have a video on the Neoprotozoic Snowball states and the now recognized complex dynamics that drove the emergence of the metazoa? 


Always love to see what you have produced video wise.  Ok I admit there was that one exception with was the episode on flowering plants where you went with the younger fossil record then oldest  fossil flower at that time, as opposed to the multiple lines for an older origin including coprolites pollen fossils and molecular clock dating of divergence times. Then paleontologists found a 50 million year older fossilized flower that looked both far more modern  or advanced from the Early Jurassic far closer to the  late Triassic origin suggested by other lines of evidence maybe we could get an up to date video on the origins of plants while addressing that nature throws curveballs like fossils of then living fossils?

text:
Humans were well spread throughout the Asian steppes, and likely encountered the Siberian unicorn. It is then possible that the unicorn myth may have started tens of thousands of years ago, inspired by the Siberian unicorn. Here’s what famous Arabic medieval traveller Ibn Fadlan wrote about how locals describe a mythical unicorn, with startling similarities to E. sibiricum: 



“Near this river (the Volga) is a vast wilderness wherein they say is an animal that is less than a camel and more like a bull in size. Its head is like the head of a camel, and its tail is like the tail of a bull, while its body is like the body of a mule, and its hooves are like the cloven hooves of a bull. In the center of its head, it has a thick round horn, which as it rises from the head of the animal gets to be thinner until it becomes like the point of a lance. The length of some of these horns is from three to five cubits (roughly 4.5-7.5 feet), and there are those that may attain to a greater or lesserlength. The animal grazes on the leaves of trees, which are quite green. When it sees a horseman, it makes straight for him, and if he happens to have under him a fast horse, he is rendered safe from it with some effort. If it overtakes him, it removes him from the back of his horse with its horn, hurls him into the air, and then catches him with its horn. It continues in this manner until it kills him. It does not bother the horse in any form or manner. They seek out this animal in the forests in order to kill it. They do that by climbing the tall trees among which it is found, and with this object in mind, they assemble a number of archers with poisoned arrows. When it stands in their midst, they shoot at it until it is severely wounded and killed by them.” 



It would truly be amazing if  E. sibiricum was the root of the unicorn myth. Such a hypothesis, though impossible to prove, is not that far fetched. So similar to what science has unearthed about this creature today, you can see where the unicorn myth started with sightings of this creature. It was rare, it left horses alone. By time it morphed into a horse.

5:00 One complete precessional cycle takes a little bit less than 26,000 years, not 23,000 years.
5:18 Earth is furthest away from the sun around 5th or 6th of July, not 3rd of July.
5:28 Earth's orbital position in winter and summer does not only depend on the precessional cycle but on apsidal precession, as well.
5:53 In the diagram on the right side the sun shouldn’t be almost exactly in the center.
6:08 If the orbit is (almost) a circle the sun is (almost) at its center and it moves away from the center when eccentricity increases. The video shows the opposite.

text:
There are a couple of inaccuracys in this video, however it's correct to our current understanding.
The main inaccuracy is the timing of the Last Glacial maximum (LGM). Regions experienced their LGM before and after the time mentioned, Putman, (2013) lists the LGM as 26.5 ka to 19 ka. Other recent studies have also suggested the use of Last Glacial Cold Period (LGCP) for this time period.

P.s. I quite happy that this channel has covered an area which I've researched for around 4 years, and happy to say they got it right and obviously did their research

text:
Great video overall but I have a nitpick.

In your mention of eccentricity you seem to claim that an eccentric orbit might have long summers and long winters. I'm pretty sure that's an either/or scenario i.e., if you have long winters you'd have short summers. I'm basing this off Kepler's second law --- a planet on an eccentric orbit will move through the part of the orbit where it's closest to the Sun more quickly than the part far from the Sun such that a line between the Sun and the planet will sweep out a constant area per unit time.

text: Green house gases aren't limited to the emissions of burning fossil fuels.  Methane is a major contributor and is produced by rotting things.  Humans, since their development of mechanised industry, have greatly increased the consumption of raw materials and the waste thereof, resulting in more rotting biological material.  In addition, mechanised industry reduced the amount of human labour necessary to create and produce what was needed though agriculture remained largely unaffected for a long time.  Well, this mechanised industry got shifted into overdrive at the beginning of the 20th century which is when human populations were sustainably living longer, consuming more over those increased years of life, it also gave rise to mechanised warfare.  Machines did (and most still do) need a lot of fossil fuel products to operate and maintain.  Some of these also resulted in explosive materials being introduced to environments where they never previously existed, even when the earliest bombs were made several hundred years before the beginning of WW I.  This further escalated when hydrogen and atomic bombs were even tested, let alone used offensively.  The point is, even though use of fossil fuels contributes, the ultimately root cause is the existence of humans who never really considered the effects of their actions then raised their noses and scoffed at being rightfully accused of contributing to a more rapid alteration of climate change.  Even without fossil fuels at all, humans have been the cause of extinctions, toxicity and elevated emissions of greenhouse gases which all play a role in climate change.  The planet and the atmosphere are a closed system.  Cause destruction of any part of it, even a seemingly insignificant part, and the whole is negatively affected.  Some things can be countered over time but at the rate humans consume and consequently produce waste, normal and natural cycles can't keep up.  Yet.  We won't survive a lot longer at the rate and in the direction we are going.  Eventually, everything will return to equilibrium.  As soon as we are extinct.
author: Gabriella Shimone

text: Gabriella Shimone Go blame China. The worst polluter on the planet now as advanced societies are reducing wastes and pollution.
author: George PPS

text: @George PPS  I blame everyone worthy of the blame.  As far as advanced societies, their corporations go to developing countries and exploit the population.  They also don't abide by the same stringent regulations they'd have to in their own countries.  Let's also not forget all the nuclear testing these "advanced" societies did without conscience, refusing to take any responsibility for the outcomes.  Even with working to reduce waste and emissions, there is a lot of toxic material still in those countries.  It will take a lot of time and a lot of work to clean up, something that gets considered only in terms of financial cost.  The ideal needs to shift to doing what it takes to clean up and not do it again without further exploitation and maintaining stringent environmental regulations (and also abiding by those).  Blame is shared, it's not any one industrialised nation, it's all of them.
author: Gabriella Shimone

text: @Gabriella Shimone  If earth self-regulates then we can't imagine the things it will throw at us - short, sharp coronavirus events, long slow sea-rise events and lots of catastrophic weather events interfering with and slowly smashing all these complicated, just-in-time systems we've built up. That's just for starters. Extinction is such a big word though. You wouldn't want to be living in a metropolis or anywhere near one, I grant you. But I imagine there would always be resilient groups hanging on in the extreme or remote margins. You might even find a billionaire's bolt-hole or two - although I imagine they'd be very unhealthy places and unlikely to survive for too many generations.

text: Did you not watch the whole video? At the end it's pointed out that emissions from human activity are adding a new variable to the cycle. For hundreds of millions of years, since the Carboniferous period, the carbon that we are currently releasing into the environment was locked away underground. It wasn't a part of the climate system, and this was rarely changed until humans came along. So yes, there is a natural cycle that the planet goes through, but human activity is disrupting that cycle. The only question is what will the effects of that disruption be.

author: Alyssa Patti

text: @Alyssa Patti  You're correct about the climate and carbon levels, but there was almost twice as much oxygen as there is today 300 million years ago. Also plenty of people live in desert climates all across the Sahara and the Middle East. Ultimately I'm pretty sure food would have been the biggest issue, as the volcanoes, though large, were still fairly localized in the grand scheme of things. Even the Siberian Traps in Russia dont really cover that much of the land percentage-wise. Food, however, would be a huge issue as humans can't really eat ferns or trees, which is really all that was around at that time. Fruits, grains, etc. wouldn't show up for over a hundred million years, so the only thing to eat would be other animals and possibly some more digestible ferns.

text:
If you want to check it out, look up the Carboniferous period. Basically when trees first evolved there weren't any microbes or bacteria that could break then down for millions of years. So trees would die, fall over, and instead of decomposing like today they would be covered by sediment. 
Another way coal formed during the Carboniferous was due to the extensive swamps that existed at the time. Many plants sunk into these swamps and, similarly to trees, weren't decomposed by other organisms, so they became coal. The latter of these processes can be seen today in peat bogs, where peat is gathered and used for fuel.

This is important in the context of climate because all of that coal is essentially carbon that had been removed from the planetary climate for hundreds of millions of years, and now we are releasing it back into the atmosphere, which is a variable that hasn't existed in the cycles talked about in the video.

text: The explanation of how the Earth's rotational axis moves is a bit simplified. It takes the Earth's axis 29,000 years to rotate in relation to the fixed stars. So where does the 23,000 years figure come from? Well, there is a second precession going on at the same time, the so called apsidal precession, during which the orientation of Earth's orbit slowly shifts. Basically, every year the perihelion (the point in Earth's orbit furthest away from the Sun) moves forward a couple of arcseconds every year, forming a cycle that repeats itself every 112,000 years. Due to these two phenome combining with each other, the rotational axis of Earth rotates once every 20,900 - 29,000 years, with an average of 23,000 years.

text: Well for a start sea level would rise by about 230 feet which would be pretty catastrophic. Global temperatures would rise significantly, global weather patterns and ocean currents would completely change, changing heat distribution around the world,  lowering temperatures in some places, raising them elsewhere. Depending on the speed of the melting species could go extinct due to habitat loss, hundreds of millions of people would starve, die of disease or be forced to relocate as growing seasons all over the world would change drastically, tropical diseases would spread into new ranges and coastal cities including ports, harbors, fishing towns flood, power stations would be lost, as would key economic cities for many countries. lakes and other key sources of fresh water would be contaminated by encroaching salt water. There would definitely be wars caused by resource shortages and even just loss of living space for coastal countries. The salinity of the ocean would drop, its temperature would rise causing significant damage to many marine ecosystems, basically utter global chaos from both a human and natural viewpoint.

author: Metamétodo

text:
@Yo Momz  Imperial is unnecesarily complicated. Metric is better because it has a uniform change of ten units and generalized prefixes that are added to any unit you want making the change (so moving through the system is extremely easy and intuitive). Plus, no one uses imperial anymore with the exception of the USA (because there is no reason to do so when metric is much simpler and easier to use). It is true that some countries use Farenheit but in that regard, Celsius and Farenheit are both bad units with the clearly better option being Kelvin. But since no one talks in Kelvin, going the more international option with Celsius makes sense (as Farenheit is only used in some english-speaking countries and nowhere else).
Oddly enough, you could have a metric progresion with one of the imperial units, like centifoot, kilofoot and stuff like that. But I'm not sure how many people will understand you.
author: Ditidos

text: @Ditidos  thing with celcius to kelvin as well is that a change of 1 degree celcius is the same as 1 degree kelvin, so it's still super easy to work with as things like specific heat capacity don't change and conversion is easy (just add the difference). Not sure about Fahrenheit as I'm merely an A level student from the U.K, but as far as I know they don't have equal changes in intervals?
author: L

text: Any timeline when we will be able to fully regenerate any part of our bodies ?
author: blacklikeme88

text: @blacklikeme88 Depends on which part of your body you want to produce (and the underlying complexity). Currently, there are some clinical trials in which we transplant tissues which arise from stem cells (which on the other hand are often made from skin cells but I will talk about this in my next video). I am personally really looking forward to reading the results of a study which tries to cure type 1 diabetes through the transplantation of insulin-producing beta cells. There are many reasons why we are currently more focusing on producing tissues rather than whole organs. One very important factor here is safety. It is very difficult to control the development of stem cells to create whole organs (we need to understand developmental processes way better). If we try to transplant something as complex as an organ we could not guarantee that cells in this organ might not become harmful for the recipient (and provoke teratoma which are tumour-like cell aggregations). I cannot precisely tell you how long it will take until we have overcome all these challenges but we are making remarkable progress (about 15 years ago we were not even able to make stem cells from skin cells)!
